page.title: 01Grizebeck and Cawthwaite
page.content: The area is divided by the ridge of Kirkby Moor and Burney Fell. The farmer is gouse moor, and the latter sheep walk. To the west the land falls steeply towards the hamlets of Grizebeck and chapels, which are dominated by the huge spoil heaps of Kirkby Moor slate quarry. To the east the ground falls slightly less steeply through disused slate quarries and the hamlet of Cawthwaite. There are ten working farms in the area, many having been bought as family or holiday homes. Farming is mainly sheep and store cattle. The name Grizbeck is also applied to the summit of the A5092 road which reachrs its highest point here (about 200ft) as it crosses from Kendall and the east to Millon and the west coast.
